channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: A Child in Yemen: ‘We Sleep Afraid, We Wake Up Afraid’
item.media:description: My son, Yousef, 2.
item.description: The bombs shake the author’s house at night and blow open doors and windows. How can he explain the war in Yemen to his children, who are living through it?
item.dc:creator: MOHAMMED al-ASAADI

item.title: Memo From Jerusalem: Tough Talk but Little Action From Lieberman as Israel’s Defense Minister
item.media:description: Israeli police officers carried the coffin of Yosef Kirma, a fellow officer, during his funeral on Sunday in Jerusalem. He was killed that day in an attack by a Palestinian gunman.
item.description: Having criticized the government five months ago for its handling of security, the hard-liner Avigdor Lieberman has not done much to reshape Israeli policies.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: ISIS Media Output Drops as Military Pressure Rises, Report Says
item.description: The Islamic State is releasing fewer propaganda items and has shifted its message away from that of a well-run caliphate.
item.dc:creator: SCOTT SHANE
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Haitian City’s Race Into 21st Century Ruined by Hurricane
item.media:description: Hurricane Matthew left Jérémie, Haiti, devastated and in a tragically familiar state of disaster.
item.description: Along with hundreds of lives, the storm wiped out much of the progress that the isolated city, Jérémie, had been making.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED

item.title: ‘Clown Hysteria’ Spreads to Britain
item.description: A mix of childish pranks and more serious menacing appears to have migrated from the United States, leading to anti-clown patrols in parts of Britain.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Maiduguri Journal: Women, Children and Razor Wire: Inside a Compound for Boko Haram Families
item.media:description: Former wives of Boko Haram commanders in June at a guarded compound in Maiduguri, Nigeria.
item.media:credit: Jane Hahn for The New York Times
item.description: Arguing that “we can’t just release them into society,” a governor in Nigeria is operating a detention center for former wives and children of commanders of a militant group.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: In India, a Day to Burn Demons Singes Pakistan, Too
item.media:description: Indians added fireworks to an effigy bearing the image of Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan in the likeness of Ravana the Hindu demon king on Monday.
item.description: The Hindu festival of Dussehra re-enacts the slaying of a 10-headed demon. But in a season of tensions, this year’s festival has taken on a Pakistani-themed motif.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY and SUHASINI RAJ

item.title: Gunmen Attack Crowded Shiite Shrine in Kabul
item.description: The attack came on the eve of Ashura, one of the most solemn holidays on the Shiite calendar.
item.dc:creator: ZAHRA NADER and MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Newspaper Closes in Hungary, and Hungarians See Government’s Hand
item.media:description: Staff members from the Hungarian newspaper Nepszabadsag outside the company’s offices in Budapest on Sunday. They were denied access.
item.description: Nepszabadsag, Hungary’s largest opposition paper, has halted publication after years of financial losses. Some also say political interference played a role.
item.dc:creator: HELENE BIENVENU

item.title: Celebrating Seamus Heaney’s Legacy, at His Birthplace
item.media:description: A bust and photograph of the poet Seamus Heaney at the new cultural center that bears his name.
item.description: A 21,000-square-foot arts center has opened in Bellaghy, Northern Ireland, where the Nobel Prize-winning poet was born.
item.dc:creator: ROSLYN SULCAS

item.title: Ilham Tohti, Uighur Scholar in Chinese Prison, Is Given Human Rights Award
item.media:description: Ilham Tohti, a Uighur scholar sentenced to life imprisonment on charges of of separatism, in 2010.
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.description: Mr. Tohti, who was jailed after speaking out against repression in his native Xinjiang, has been depicted by Beijing as promoting separatism.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Refugee’s Capture in Germany Is Said to Thwart Terrorist Attack
item.media:description: Police officers at an apartment building in Chemnitz, Germany, on Saturday, where they found more than three pounds of material believed to be TATP, an explosive used in terrorist attacks in France last year.
item.description: The head of the federal domestic intelligence service indicated that the likely target was a Berlin airport and that the suspect had ties to ISIS.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: Sinosphere: For China’s Leaders, U.S. Election Scandals Make the Case for One-Party Rule
item.media:description: Students watching an online broadcast of the first United States presidential debate at a cafe in Beijing last month.
item.description: Even before the most recent scandal involving Donald J. Trump, the Chinese news media has depicted him and Hillary Clinton as puppets of wealthy elites.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Reporter Who Wrote of Military-Civilian Clash Says He Can’t Leave Pakistan
item.description: The journalist said he had been placed on an “exit control list” days after reporting a confrontation over the military’s handling of Islamist groups.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Vietnam Arrests Mother Mushroom, a Top Blogger, for Criticizing Government
item.media:description: The Vietnamese blogger Nguyen Ngoc Nhu Quynh in 2015.
item.description: Nguyen Ngoc Nhu Quynh, a co-founder of the Network of Vietnamese Bloggers, has challenged leaders over topics including a dump of toxic chemicals.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Putin Postpones Visit to France Amid Diplomatic Tensions
item.media:description: President François Hollande of France, left, in Moscow last year with his Russian counterpart, Vladimir V. Putin.
item.description: President Vladimir Putin of Russia has indefinitely postponed a trip to France after Paris had revised its program for the visit and said it would talk about nothing else but the Syrian crisis.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Letter From Europe: In Face of ‘Brexit,’ Signs of E.U. Pulling Together
item.media:description: Demonstrators in London showed support in June for leaving the European Union. Smaller states in the bloc, in particular, seem to have developed a greater sense of its worth since the referendum.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: No other country has threatened to leave, and smaller states in particular seem to have developed a greater sense of the bloc’s worth.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: The Interpreter: Trump’s Threat to Jail Clinton Also Targets Democracy’s Institutions
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton on Sunday night in St. Louis during their second debate. Mr. Trump said Mrs. Clinton would “be in jail” if he were president.
item.description: His claim at Sunday’s presidential debate was “a threat to the rule of law,” one political scientist said.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER and AMANDA TAUB

item.title: Sinosphere: Henan Province, a Butt of Jokes in China, Gets a Champion in Court
item.media:description: Tourists crowding ancient Buddhist sculptures at the Longmen Grottoes in Luoyang, in the central Chinese province of Henan, during the recent National Day holiday. Henan is celebrated as a birthplace of Chinese civilization but disparaged by some for a less glorious present.
item.description: After an aspiring TV celebrity ridiculed the province, a science journalist from the region resolved to sue for damages to his reputation as a resident there.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Building Collapse in Chinese City of Wenzhou Kills at Least 22
item.description: The toll makes it one of the deadliest episodes of its kind in recent years. Six people have been pulled from the rubble, including a 3-year-old girl.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Australia’s Labor Party Blocks Referendum on Same-Sex Marriage
item.media:description: Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull of Australia, right, and the leader of the opposition Labor Party, Bill Shorten, in Canberra in August.
item.description: The party voted unanimously to block a nonbinding plebiscite proposed for early next year, calling it “the wrong path to achieve marriage equality.”
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

item.title: Car Attacks in Denmark Spread ‘Like an Infection’
item.media:description: A car fire last month in Malmo, Sweden, where more than 70 vehicles have been burned since early July. Investigators in Copenhagen, the Danish capital, say the spike in arson in Denmark may be related to the Swedish car burnings.
item.media:credit: Johan Nilsson/TT NEWS AGENCY, via Associated Press
item.description: Nearly 190 cars have been set ablaze in Copenhagen this year, a violent outburst that is upsetting a country that prides itself on its social harmony.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Ex-President of Brazil Faces New Corruption Charges
item.media:description: Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva last month after a news conference.
item.description: Charges have been filed against Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva concerning dealings in Angola, but he is still a leading contender for president in 2018.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Nadia Murad, Yazidi Woman Who Survived ISIS Captivity, Wins Human Rights Prize
item.media:description: Nadia Murad, a former prisoner of the Islamic State, spoke after being awarded the Vaclav Havel Human Rights Prize at the Council of Europe on Monday in Strasbourg, France.
item.description: Abducted by Islamic State militants in Iraq in 2014, she has become a good-will ambassador for victims of human trafficking.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN and SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Trilobites: Jamaican Rock Iguanas Get a Shot at a New Home in the Wild
item.media:description: The Jamaican rock iguana, a critically endangered species, is making a comeback.
item.description: A decision on the siting of a seaport could improve the prospects of the restoration of the lizards, which were once believed to be extinct.
item.dc:creator: JOANNA KLEIN

item.title: Warming Relations in Person, Putin and Erdogan Revive Pipeline Deal
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin and President Recep Tayyip Erdogan said they would proceed with a natural-gas pipeline under the Black Sea.
item.description: At an energy conference in Istanbul, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia agreed with President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey to proceed with the suspended Turkish Stream pipeline project.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries

item.title: Dozens Believed Killed as Violence Erupts in Myanmar
item.media:description: Police officers in Maungdaw, Myanmar, on Sunday, after deadly attacks near the border with Bangladesh.
item.description: The bloodshed in Rakhine State, home to members of the Rohingya Muslim minority, was set off by attacks on police posts.
item.dc:creator: WAI MOE

item.title: With Colombia’s Peace Deal in Doubt, a Battered Town Fears a Return to War
item.media:description: At least 79 people, more than half of them children, were killed when a mortar struck a church in Bellavista, Colombia, in 2002.
item.description: “We’re tired of so much violence,” said a resident of rural Bojayá, where 14 years after a guerrilla mortar killed dozens inside a church, 96 percent of voters supported an accord.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Sinosphere: Taiwan’s President Calls for New Talks With Beijing
item.media:description: President Tsai Ing-wen of Taiwan delivering a speech on Monday in Taipei during National Day celebrations.
item.description: In her first National Day speech, Tsai Ing-wen emphasized that Beijing should acknowledge the island’s choice to become a democracy.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Sinosphere: Tourists Behaving Badly: Name-and-Shame Effort Fails to Fix China’s Image
item.media:description: Chinese visitors at Gyeongbok Palace in Seoul, South Korea, during China’s weeklong National Day holiday.
item.description: Brawling, vandalism and other boorish acts at home and abroad have raised doubts about the effectiveness of a “tourism blacklist” set up last year.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Syrian, Feared to Be Planning Bombing, Is Arrested in Germany
item.media:description: Police officers examined an apartment on Monday in Leipzig, Germany. The police said they arrested Jaber al-Bakr, 22, in the city, roughly an hour north of Chemnitz, where he had been living.
item.description: The capture ended a manhunt as fears rose of a threat posed by extremists who were among the refugees and migrants who arrived in the country last year.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: U.N. Chief Condemns Airstrike on Yemeni Funeral and Dismisses Saudi Denials
item.description: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon said he supported demands for an inquiry into whether the attack, which killed at least 140 people, was a war crime.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: What in the World: When You Have to Go, Japanese Rest Stops Won’t Keep You Waiting
item.media:description: Monitors at the rest stop let visitors see immediately which stalls inside the restroom are empty.
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.description: Amenities like five times as many stalls for women, and monitors showing the vacant ones, aim to make sure traffic is the only delay to worry about.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: What in the World: You Say ‘Anguria,’ I Say ‘Cocomero’: Italy’s Many Dialects
item.description: The country has hundreds of local variations on language, each with its own quirks of pronunciation, inflection and vocabulary, which can make daily interactions confusing.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Trumpism After Trump
item.media:description: Donald Trump addressing Hillary Clinton during the second presidential debate on Sunday in St. Louis.
item.description: If the American anger and dread that fed Trump’s rise are not addressed, the consequences will be dire.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Putin in Syria: Chechnya All Over Again
item.media:description: Aleppo’s historic citadel in October 2014.
item.description: The Kremlin wants to bomb Aleppo into submission and impose peace via a local strongman, just like it did in Grozny a decade and a half ago.
item.dc:creator: OLIVER BULLOUGH

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Venezuela in a Vise
item.description: The government’s efforts to block a referendum against President Maduro are undemocratic and unconstitutional — and a betrayal of Hugo Chávez.
item.dc:creator: FRANCISCO TORO

item.title: Postcard From the Hajj: A Pilgrim’s Progress: Checking Mecca Off My Bucket List
item.media:description: “Pilgrims surprised me with their warmth.”
item.description: This reporter’s long-dreamed-of journey to explore the heart of Islam revealed surprises, debunked stereotypes and produced one stunning bird video.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Postscript: One Year Later, a Tip About a Border Crossing Pays Off
item.media:description: Laborers transported ammonium nitrate at the crossing from Akcakale, Turkey, into Syria in April 2015. The compound, a common fertilizer, has been used by terrorists to create explosives.
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.description: How New York Times reporting may have made the Middle East just a little bit safer.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and KARAM SHOUMALI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT
